channel.title: Comments on: Fun With Data & Goal-Setting

item.title: By: llong
item.dc:creator: llong
item.description:
Are you able to get member data? I'd love to see stats on how many goals people have on their lists, how many they have accomplished, how many they have given up on, and who has the most of these categories!
By the way, I've been a 43things member for about 6 years.
item.content:encoded:
Are you able to get member data? I’d love to see stats on how many goals people have on their lists, how many they have accomplished, how many they have given up on, and who has the most of these categories!

By the way, I’ve been a 43things member for about 6 years.

item.title: By: Danuta Electra
item.dc:creator: Danuta Electra
item.description: It is interesting to see that write a book is te least achieved goal. Do people set up subgoals to assist them with these tasks? For instance, you write there are goals we complete but do view as goals, such as graduating from school or college. These goals are long commitment and complex to achieve. The reasons why we achieve them are structural. Firstly, society creates a structure where people are required to complete these goals: there are external expectations and supports. Secondly, school and college students are bonded into cohort groups, and the closer these cohorts, and more driven and talented a cohort, the more likely the cohort is to succeed. Finally, these achievements are broken down into small, achievable subgoals, such as complete grade 5, and from that, complete algebra 1, and even more refined than that, complete algebra quiz on Tuesday. Do you think that the real problem with large goals is that people do not create the structures necessary to complete them? Ta :D
item.content:encoded: It is interesting to see that write a book is te least achieved goal. Do people set up subgoals to assist them with these tasks? For instance, you write there are goals we complete but do view as goals, such as graduating from school or college. These goals are long commitment and complex to achieve. The reasons why we achieve them are structural. Firstly, society creates a structure where people are required to complete these goals: there are external expectations and supports. Secondly, school and college students are bonded into cohort groups, and the closer these cohorts, and more driven and talented a cohort, the more likely the cohort is to succeed. Finally, these achievements are broken down into small, achievable subgoals, such as complete grade 5, and from that, complete algebra 1, and even more refined than that, complete algebra quiz on Tuesday. Do you think that the real problem with large goals is that people do not create the structures necessary to complete them? Ta ðŸ˜€

item.title: By: Gail
item.dc:creator: Gail
item.description:
There is a popular novel writing goal on 43 Things that is often achieved. The wording changes annually and amongst goal setters but it is in effect one goal and that is win NaNoWriMo.
This stands for National Novel Writing Month and that is November each year. To win one must complete a 50000 word novel within the month.
If all the NaNoWriMo goals were combined into one for charting purposes it is likely that goal would be amongst the achieved rather than not achieved goals.
item.content:encoded:
There is a popular novel writing goal on 43 Things that is often achieved. The wording changes annually and amongst goal setters but it is in effect one goal and that is win NaNoWriMo.

This stands for National Novel Writing Month and that is November each year. To win one must complete a 50000 word novel within the month.

If all the NaNoWriMo goals were combined into one for charting purposes it is likely that goal would be amongst the achieved rather than not achieved goals.

item.title: By: martha
item.dc:creator: martha
item.description: Thanks for your comment, Emily. I know, we should all send them email to encourage them to get going! And to the Frank Sinatra guy (or gal) too!
item.content:encoded: Thanks for your comment, Emily. I know, we should all send them email to encourage them to get going! And to the Frank Sinatra guy (or gal) too!

item.title: By: Emily
item.dc:creator: Emily
item.description:
Fantastic post!
I can't believe 30,000 people want to write a book and another 10,000 want to write a novel. Think of all the untapped potential! The empty library shelves!
item.content:encoded:
Fantastic post!

I can’t believe 30,000 people want to write a book and another 10,000 want to write a novel. Think of all the untapped potential! The empty library shelves!

item.title: By: Fun With 43 Things Data | The Robot Co-op

item.title: By: martha
item.dc:creator: martha
item.description: Ha, thanks Jodi :) Glad you enjoyed it, it was really fun to look at the data and find the interesting observations. Will be helpful for the other project as well, but considering playing with their API to see if I can connect frequency of updates to success rates or something useful like that.
item.content:encoded: Ha, thanks Jodi ðŸ™‚ Glad you enjoyed it, it was really fun to look at the data and find the interesting observations. Will be helpful for the other project as well, but considering playing with their API to see if I can connect frequency of updates to success rates or something useful like that.

item.description: Thanks for this -- really interesting to see the analysis, as well as hear how you did it. And of course, hear your wisdom on goalsetting, Martha. :)
